titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: The temple clock struck six, when the disk of the Sun was about half risen. Till then I saw Venus, but then she vanished from my sight— The sky was crystal clear, and the Mercury in my Dresden thermometer at 32.

The names in the margin are of the members of the Committee of the Liberty party of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, who visited me this morning. They have appointed this day week for a convention to nominate a candidate for election to the house of Representatives of the United States in the 29th. Congress.— They have heretofore not nominated a candidate against me—but they will at this time, and it is highly probable will defeat the election— They were however to me this day peculiarly courteous and civil— Mr Fisher said they had no disposition to dictate opinions to me, nor to ask any pledge of me, which it might be disagreeable to me to give, but they had come to the conclusion that they were under obligations of duty to vote exclusively for persons who entertained certain opinions on the subject of Slavery, and all they were fully aware of the great and frequent services that they were indebted to me for, in support of the cause which they had so much at heart, they wished for this friendly interview to ascertain my opinions on certain points upon which there was considerable adversity among those generally opposed to Slavery.— I told them that I would cheerfully give to them my opinions as they were sincerely entertained, upon any and every point interesting to them— That I had no motive to conceal or disguise any of my opinions upon subjects of public concernment— That I had lived 77 years and served in various offices, and never asked or solicited directly or indirectly the vote of any man, and thought it not worth while to commence the practise now— I answered all their questions; discussed with them the points upon which we did not concur— The vote for President upon which I should not be the partizan of any man.— We considered the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia and the territories and the prohibition of the interstate Slave-trade. They declared themselves perfectly satisfied with the interview— One of them said he should vote for me with pleasure—another said he did not know but what he should— The rest were silent. I asked them for their names; which one of them brought me on cards, from French’s tavern where they dined Mr Fisher said they expected at this election to cast from 1400 to 1600 votes. Charles and his wife were here this Evening.

The temple clock, struck six as about 4 digits of the Sun’s disk had appeared above the horizon, and as he rose Venus vanished from sight on the firmament— My visitors yesterday from the Committee of the Liberty party were apparently not of one mind when they came nor yet when they left me. My opposition to the immediate abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, and in the Territories, they all disapprove, and Mr Howe the late Senator from Norfolk County in the State Legislature pressed me specially with the question whether Congress have not the power to repeal the Laws of the District which allow and sanction Slavery— With regard to the inter-state Slave trade I told them I had no doubt of the power of Congress to prohibit that, and would vote for a bill to that effect to-morrow, though it would not be possible to prevail upon the house to receive such a bill— I told them I regretted that I could not concur with them in all their opinions, and still more the dissensions prevailing among themselves— The Colonization Society— The Anti-Slavery and abolition Societies—the no-government non resisting and women membered Societies— I grieved also at their classing in the same level of exclusion the whig and democrat parties.— I thought there was a great difference between them; and that placing them on the same level was to secure the triumph of the worst party— This tendency of all private associations to settle into factious cabals is the besetting sin of all elective governments— I had no visitors this day— This Evening my Son, with Walter Hellen, Mary Louisa, and Louisa Catherine and John Quincy whom they took up in Boston, went to the Melodeon, and saw the Tragedy of Hamlet performed, the part of Hamlet by Macready— It was close upon 1. of to-morrow morning when they got home excepting John Quincy 3. who remained in Boston to attend the Latin school— I received this morning from Mr N. Frye at Washington the daily Globe of 20 March 1844. containing the Letters of Aaron Vail Brown and Andrew Jackson upon the annexation of Texas to the United States— I employed so industriously this day that besides the daily record I wrote 4 pages of my task, only to prove what with diligence can do in one day.— The danger now is that I shall do too much—slide into dulness, wander into impertinence, fret into ribaldry and worry into tediousness— The conspiracy against my good name is so complicated, so combined so crafty and so base that I can scarcely keep my self-command to meet it—
Sun rose 5.58. Set 5.40 with sprinkle of rain.

Th temple Clock struck 6 with the first beam of the Sun emerging from the eastern hill over the corner of Captain Underwood’s house— I had no interruption of visitors except from a Mr Tirrell who came to dispose of tickets for a convivial party of the members of the Quincy fire companies at 1. O’Clock p.m to-morrow— I took ten tickets and promised to attend the meeting in person, if I should find it convenient— My Son went this morning with his son Charles Francis to the granite quarries, where Mr Lemuel Humphrey of Weymouth had engaged to meet him to make a survey and take a plan of a lot of mine there— He intended to have returned home to dinner; but the work took the day, and was still left unfinished— At the setting of the Sun I went up the hill where his wife told me that he had not returned and she knew not where he was— I came back to enquire of Benjamin F Andrews where he had left him this morning; but James Davenport their servant followed close after me and told me that Mr Charles with his Son had returned. Though I had the whole day for my labour I was able to write only three pages of my task, and find I shall be obliged to curtail and concentrate much of what I have yet to say on Monday next— In the Evening Charles came down—without his wife, and I read to the family what I have already written for the address of next Monday.— It occupied an hour and a half, and I suppressed the reading of several documents, which I must not pass over next Monday.— I must bespeak the patience of my hearers a full hour longer and then abridge and leave out— But what is worse my language is too violent, and must be smoothed down, I know not how nor to what extent—further I have now only four days more to finish, and must leave space for a final recapitulation— I read myself this evening quite hoarse, and took warning to pitch my voice quite low when I begin— All my correspondence lags behind and I leave unanswered numerous invitations, and complimentary Letters. Walter Hellen has completed for me a large collection of extracts from my Diary of 1818 and 1819. which I much wanted at Washington last Winter; and of which I want that more than one copy should be in existence to guard against the casualty of fire, and the possibility of theft or mutilation— The Steamer Caledonia arrived from Liverpool at Boston this morning at ten O’Clock, in the average Summer passage of 14 days, and with the average number of 101. passengers.

Rain storm from early morning till late this afternoon— I thought I should have a long uninterrupted day, but was sadly disappointed. As the evening twilight came on I took my hat to go up to Charles’s house, when two strangers came in and introduced themselves as Mr Wilson of Missouri and Mr Haven of New-York city— They are whig politicians and came to see me from mere curiosity to see and talk with me— Mr Wilson said he had been settled in Missouri nearly 25. years, and most of that time in opposition to Coll. Thomas H Benton, whose recent movements against the annexation of Texas were caused by his knowledge that nothing else could have saved him politically in Missouri— The people there were all of them perfectly willing to take Texas, and to fight the Mexicans, or the British—but they have an abhorrence to being burdened to pay the debt of Texas which they know will amount to nearer twenty five than ten millions of dollars, and they know that if Texas should be annexed to the United States there will not come to them one acre of ungranted land— Mr Wilson discoursed thus for at least an hour with little interruption from me— Mr Haven said little— I invited them to take tea with us, but they said it was growing late and they must return to Boston— They were scarcely gone, and our tea table cleared when Mr Edward M. Clymer a Student at the Law school at Cambridge, came with a Letter of recommendation from his uncle William Hiester of New Holland Pennsylvania— Mr Clymer’s object was only to spend an evening with us which he did— He is a pleasant very well bred and sociable young man, whom I regretted not to have convenient means to pass the Night with us. Charles and his wife also spent the evening here— The news by the Caledonia and other newspaper intelligence absorbed hours, and a private Letter from George W. Erving to me in the pamphlet, of 1. March 1818 referred me to one that I had received from in London after my appointment as Secretary of State, and before I embarked to return home. Walter Hellen searched and found it for me and with it a file of Letters from him received by me in England from 1815 to 1817. The one of which I was in search contained a quotation from a Latin poet, not of the hacknied class, and I lost some time in searching for it, in vain— And more time in reading over the file.

Mr John J. Carr the tenant of my homested farm came to me this morning from a whig committee with a subscription paper promising to pay blank sums, for the circulating papers among the people; and other expenses of the Committee, which I declined to subscribe, observing to Mr Carr that I thought there would be an impropriety in my contributing money for such a purpose, and by the indefinite terms in which the paper was drawn up it would be the incipient entrance upon a practise making all elections venal, and setting up all public offices at auction to the highest bidder. Mr Dudley Williams of Roxbury with his wife was here with a Document certified by John G. Palfrey Secretary of the Commonwealth, being the declaration of Hannah Allen now widow of Richard Allen, but heretofore widow of Zebulon Thayer, and a claimant for a pension— Her maiden name was White, and she says she went to school with me to Nathan Rice— Besides her declaration there are affidavits of Bryant Newcomb, and Dudley Williams—and Certificates from Judson Stoddard town Clark of Braintree—Samuel F. M’Cleary City Clerk, William T. Andrews Justice of the Peace and Sherman Leland judge of Probate for the County— Mr Williams requested me to transmit these papers to the commissioners of pensions which I promised to do. Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks came out from Boston, and dined with My Son up the hill— They went to Europe in 1842 for the recovery of his health, in which he has been partially successeul.— They returned in the last Steamer, and are to resume in a few weeks their residence at New-York— There he has been many years in partnership of trade with Charles Augustus Davis— They returned to Boston immediately after dinner, and they were scarcely gone, when Charles’s wife was taken suddenly ill and took to her bed— Dr Woodward was sent for, and I came home in grief and alarm from the house to which I had gone for festivity and joy.— How pungent is the feeling of such vicissitudes! I laboured hard at my task— Walter Hellen found for me the file of Letters from George W. Erving, which I received in England from 1815 to 1817. and among them was the one I wanted, an exquisite curiosity at this day— A Letter from Madrid of 3. May 1817. containing a classical quotation of Latin poetry, which after diligent search, consuming no small time I found was from Propertius 2.20.32— Three lines and two words— They are the key to Mr George W. Erving’s Revelation’s to President Jackson in 1829 and 1832— They were a supplication to me from Erving to raise him from the Hell of Madrid to the Heaven of Paris.

I attend meeting at the Temple in the hope of composing my shattered nerves and abstracting my agitated bosom from the cares of the world and the interests of Time— This is peculiarly my desire on the days when I partake of the communion— This day, with sorrow I says was too much absorbed by this world, and too little to that at the verge of which I stand— Heaven forgive me for it! Mr Lunt preached this morning from John 12.27. [“]Now is my soul troubled; and what shall I say? Father, save me from this hour; but for this cause came I unto this hour.” This is part of a discourse of Jesus only six days before his last Passover at Bethany where he had performed the miracle of raising Lazarus from the dead— Here it was that between the worship of those who had witnessed the miracle and believed him to be the Messiah; and the compassing of his death by those who disbelieved, which was within one week of being consummated, his soul was troubled— He revealed himself and the destiny that awaited him, in figurative and, somewhat misterious, discourse, not understood even by his disciples, until explained by his subsequent death and resurrection; and foretold at once his suffering and his glorification— Mr Lunt’s view of his text appeared to me ingenious and impressive as he delivered his sermon; but other thoughts were forcing themselves upon my memory while he spoke, and my soul was like one of those sheets of antient parchments, upon which a poem in monkish rhyme is written over an Oration of Cicero. Mr Lunt administered the communion and the usual annual collection was taken up to defray the expenses of this ordinance— He also reminded the members of the church of a resolution within the last year adopted, that two blank books should be purchased, one for a copy to be made in it of the antient records of the church, and the other in which the future records may be kept— The change in the time of meeting from ten, to half past ten in the morning, and from a quarter past to a quarter before 2. in the afternoon commenced this day.— On returning from the morning service I found Mr Degrand who dined and spent the day with us.— After dinner Mr Joseph Angier of Milton preached in exchange with Mr Lunt, from James 2.8. “If ye fulfil the royal law, according to the scripture, Thou shalt love thy neighbour, as thyself, ye do well”— Mr Degrand left us to return to Boston about 7. in the evening, and from that time till midnight I was writing at my task without coming to a close— Charles had gone to Boston this morning, was at meeting this afternoon, and here this Evening.

This was one of the epochal days of my life— On the 26th of last month my son brought me the Boston Post of 25. March containing Andrew Jackson’s Letter to Aaron Vail Brown of 12. Feby 1843. The next morning I found on my file, the semi-weekly Globe of 21. March 1844 containing Brown’s Letter to the Editors of the Globe, with Jackson’s Letter for publication— I determined to make them the text of the address which I had promised to deliver to the young men’s whig club of Boston this Evening.— I thought this a suitable occasion for opening my defence before the country and the world, against the conspiracy of Andrew Jackson, Aaron Vail Brown, George W. Erving and Charles J. Ingersoll, with their coadjutors and tools, to ruin my good name, and fabricate a fable to justify the robbery of Texas from Mexico, by the pretence that Texas had been by me treacherously surrendered to Spain— I began the address that day, and finished it this day just in time for dinner— The composition therefore is excessively hurried and unskilfully put together, with sundry repetitions, which needed a pruning hand; but I had no time to give— At 6 O’Clock this afternoon I rode into Boston with my Son and Walter Hellen, and precisely at 7. alighted at the Tremont Temple— I was there received with the utmost simplicity by the Committee of the young men’s whig club, in a private room adjoining the hall which was already crowded as full as it could hold— Several of my elderly friends were assembled in this private room and I was specially greeted by Samuel T. Armstrong, Jeremiah Mason, Abbott Lawrence, Stephen C. Phillips, Robert C. Winthrop, Josiah Quincy junr. Samuel H. Walley junr. and several others. Mr Hayden Editor of the Boston Atlas, Erastus Brooks of the New-York Evening Express, and the younger Buckingham, applied for the use of my manuscript for immediate publication in their respective papers— I gave it with a pledge that I should have a proof sheet to revise before publication, to Mr Hayden the first applicant— At precisely half past 7. I entered the Hall with my Son, who is President of the club, and with the chairman of the Committee of the Club. The reception was complimentary and enthusiastic, and my Son said that after such a reception, it would be superfluous for him to do more than announce to them the name of his father John Quincy Adams—whereupon another shout of welcome shook the house— A young Mr Coffin at my request read the Letters of Aaron Vail Brown and of Andrew Jackson, and I discoursed upon them two hours and ten minutes much to the amusement of the Auditory— The closing Apostrophe to the young men of Boston was specially well received. As soon as the crowd was cleared away we re-entered the Carriage; left my son at the United States Hotel, and with Walter Hellen I returned to Quincy—reaching home at eleven.

In the hurry of preparation for the last evening my diary has run three days in arrear, and the high excitement of yesterday with more than two hours of loud speaking, preceded and followed by the rides have left upon me a feverish lassitude, and longing for a vacation ill-suited to my condition— I am to address my constituents the people of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts before the last of this month— I ought to have been at work upon it this day but could not bring myself to it. I allowed myself about three hours to transport three seedling stocks of pear trees, and one shag-bark walnut tree from the Nursery to the Seminary: a very hazardous operation, and of the success of which I despair even while undertaking it. The trees are of six or seven years growth and would flourish in their native soil; but they stand too near other yet more valuable trees, and must be removed from their proximity—the walnut had a double tap root which John Kirk could not extract from the rock-bound soil, and of which he cut off with the spade a large portion— My Son remained last Night in Boston, and took lodging at the United States Hotel to start early this morning on the Western Railroad for Springfield, where he is to address a whig Meeting this Evening— To morrow and Thursday he is to perform the same service at other places; and to return home next Friday. The Atlas and the Boston Courier of this morning have notices of the meeting of the Young men’s whig club last Evening at the Tremont Temple, and very commendatory accounts of my Address which the Atlas promises to give from my Manuscript Notes to-morrow— But I received no proof sheet. I had engaged to pass the Night at Mr James H Foster’s if I had remained in the City. Mr Josiah Quincy junr. also offered me a bed, and judge John Davis engaged me to dine with him on the next day of Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society— My time was so wholly absorbed yesterday that I could not even read the Boston Morning Newspapers— The State-elections keep up the political agitation— The accounts from Delaware are very equivocal—from Maryland encouraging, but with a dark spot from the City of Baltimore. From Pennsylvania and New-York they are desperate, and the general result is equally so. Maine has gone by a majority of more than ten thousand for free trade and Texas.— It is hard to steer and row against wind and tide; but even in the agony of death we must say like Lawrence don’t give up the ship.

The moon had just risen when I rose, and having been yesterday in conjunction with Venus, I hoped to see them both at the rising of the Sun; but as the morning dawn advanced a hazy vapour arose and covered the atmosphere—the Sun rose with a crimson colour, and a smoky outline, and the day was the entrance to the Indian Summer.— I redeemed the arrears of my Diary, and began an address to my constituents, which I propose to have in readiness for the 30th. of this month— But it will absorb all my time so that I can do nothing else— I set out upon a new plan, and consider all that I have written from the 13th. of July when I got home till the 26th. of September as waste paper. My Address to the young whigs of Boston was published entire in the Boston Atlas of this day; but the paper did not come to me— The Morning Chronicle, the Liberty party paper of yesterday had not even a notice of the Meeting of the whig club of the night before— This day it has a very favourable account of the Address, specially remarking that there was not a word in it about the Presidential election or the Presidential candidates— Yesterday was the day of the Meeting of the Liberty party Convention to nominate candidates for Senators for the County of Norfolk; and for a member of the House of Representatives of the United States for the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts in the 29th. Congress. I received on Monday two Letters from John Gulliver, of Roxbury, one of the Liberty party Committee, who conferred with me on the 1st. of this month—extremely anxious between the fear that the Meeting would, and the hope that they would not nominate a Candidate against me— There is in the Morning Chronicle of this day no notice of the Meeting at Dedham yesterday— The Democratic party have nominated Isaac G. Wright who was last year one of the Senators for the County of Norfolk in the Legislature of the State. Mr Josiah Savil came this afternoon to enquire concerning certain papers, which he says were put into my brother Thomas’s hands shortly before his death, relating to the claim of Charles Newcomb, a revolutionary Soldier for bounty Lands— Newcomb was a pensioner under the act of Congress of 1818. The pension was revoked by the act of 1820.— He died soon after the papers were put into my brothers hands—and his widow Jerusha Newcomb who was a daughter of Micajah Adams is now entitled to a pension by the 5 years laws.— I referred Mr Savil to Mr Gourgas for the papers, and asked him for a written statement, to which I would attend.

I went up the hill to see both the rising and setting of the Sun, but before he rose the haze gathering over the Eastern horizon thickened so that I could discern only the outline of his disk, and at his setting although distinctly visible till he drew within a disk’s distance of the western, he had totally disappeared behind the haze before reaching its border. It was a genuine Indian Summer day, occupied as I would that all my days should be, with no unnecessary intermission, and writing the record of yesterday, and three pages of task— I cannot do more— Mr Beman is a coloured man about 3 4ths. white who came with a subscription paper for the Methodist-Episcopal Zion Church at Boston.— He is the Pastor of that Church, and one of the Clerks in the morning Chronicle Office.— A young man by the name of Ebenezer Wiley from South Reading in the County of Middlesex came to see me, from motives of mere curiosity— I was somewhat inquisitive about himself, but he was not much disposed to talk about himself, and I did not press enquiry.— Henry Hardwick came again to propose the purchase of that corner of land behind his house, which he has so long coveted. I promised to go and see the place or to ask my son to see it, for Mr Hardwick assured me repeatedly assured me that he would give for it double what it was worth— I paid to my wife the bequest of her brother Thomas B. Johnson and she went into Boston this afternoon, with her two Grand daughters Mary Louisa and Louisa Catherine and Walter Hellen— He brought me out the Boston Atlas of yesterday containing my address to the young men’s whig Club of Monday Evening published entire but with sundry considerable errors of the press.— About half of my address copied from the Atlas is published in the Boston Courier and in the Daily Advertiser of this day. The latter with a very favourable editorial notice— The first accounts came in this day of State Government elections in New-Jersey and Pennsylvania— The first favourable to the whigs— The second far otherwise— Both parties have Committees remaining at Washington during the recess, to superintend the issuing of documents and the circulation of intelligence— Willis Green of Kentucky is the Chairman of the whig-Committee— Robert J. Walker the Senator from Mississippi chairman of the democracy.— Walker printed a pamphlet—an Address of the Democratic Association at Washington D.C— Headed the South in Danger— Read before you vote.— Green undertook to circulate the same pamphlet in the North and the Democrats charged him with forgery.

My time is so thoroughly consumed in reading and writing on days occupied as this has been, that when it has passed I have nothing to tell— I had two Pear trees and two plum trees transplanted into the Nursery, and devoted an hour to the thinning of my seedlings in the Nursery. The two persons by the name of Coe were strangers from Connecticut the first, Minister of an episcopal church at Bethlehem, Litchfield County and the other from Winchester in the same County. They came to see me, merely for curiosity and the younger brother said that if he had returned home without seeing me, his father would not have forgiven him. My Son came back from his excursion to Springfield, Westfield and Cabotville where he has been making speeches the last three evenings— He comes with a severe cold, and weary of the office he had undertaken— Ruth Turner was here at work; Walter Hellen went to Boston to see Macready perform in a new Tragedy called the Bridal— I examined at last the publication in the Atlas of my Address to the young men’s whig club. The remainder of it is published in the Boston Courier, and I suppose in the Daily Advertiser of this day.— There are a few mistakes of the press in the Atlas—none of much importance except the word vaccination for buccination, which is ridiculous, and the more so because buccination is not a legitimate word, but one which I sported for the benefit of Aaron Vail Brown— Buccino is the Latin word for swelling the cheek to blow the trumpet or the horn, and there is a picture in the word— I made a noun substantive of it by the common analogy of Latin verbs turned into english nouns.— The compositor of the Atlas was not scholar enough to perceive it and substituted for it a word, which turned the whole sentence into nonsense— The returns of the elections continue to come in most unpropitious— The whigs have indeed carried the election in New Jersey and Stratton will be the Governor of the State— But Pennsylvania is irretrievably sunk in Democracy, and her most popular statesmen are trickish and unsafe— My projected address expands as I proceed— I am still wandering among first principles and generalities— I wish to call the attention of my countrymen to the pernicious feature of the slave-representation in the Government of the United States; but the people are so broken to it, that it is of no avail to expose it— I have yet much to unfold of the Tennessean conspiracy of Jackson, Erving, Aaron Vail Brown and Charles Jared Ingersoll against me, but I am yet uncertain whether now is the most favourable time for completing the exposure, or whether to wait.

I directed sundry pear, plum and apple trees to be transplanted but I cannot spare half an hour from 4 in the morning till ten at Night, without losing at least a page of my task, and when I once relax, it ends with the failure of the purpose before me— By the Quincy Patriot of this day it appears that the Convention of the Liberty party at Dedham last Tuesday nominated Appleton Howe of Weymouth for election to Congress for the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts— He was one of the Committee from the Liberty party who visited me last week; and John Gulliver another of them, is nominated as a Senator for the County of Norfolk— Howe has been several years a Senator from the County of Norfolk, and is a Major General of the Militia. Isaac H. Wright the nominee of the Democratic Convention was last year a Senator from the County; and this double nomination renders the question of the majority for the whole district more than doubtful— Walter Hellen returned from Boston, having seen Macready perform last Night in the Bridal, a Tragedy said to be revived from Beaumont and Fletcher.— My Son went also to Boston and returned to dinner.— I received 25 copies of the Boston Atlas of the 9th. containing my address to the young men’s whig club with all its imperfections on its head— I had them folded up to distribute, but sent only 3. to William Greene of Cincinnati, William H. Seward of Auburn and to Christopher Morgan of the same place.— There are errors of the manuscript and errors of the press, which ought to be corrected, and for which I may be obliged to have a pamphlet edition printed at my own expence.— It may be advisable however to wait for the replications of Jackson, Erving, Brown and Charles J. Ingersoll with all of whom I have yet hard work to go through— I do not deceive myself— A more formidable conspiracy against the good name of an honest public man never was plotted, and besides numerous understrappers they are four to one against me— I must sleep in armour and be ready to meet them in Indian warfare— I called at the Stone bank, for my bank book and found I had made a mistake in my casting up, and overdrawn 36.62. which I immediately rectified and had the book balanced— I called also at the Quincy Aurora Office to enquire if they intended to publish my address— The answer was affirmative but faint— I received this evening an invitation from George H. Halsey, Chairman of the Committee of arrangements of the Young Men’s Henry Clay Associations of the City of New-York to redeliver at the Tabernacle on the evening of the 22d my Address to the young men of Boston.

The sharpest morning of the Season yet— A more splendid exhibition of the starry firmament I never witnessed than that of this morning immediately after I arose— And among the numberless multitudes of assembled worlds, the planet Mercury shot his seldom visible but brilliant solitary beam into my window, about a quarter of an hour risen precisely in the track in which he was to be followed by the Sun— I ought to have seen the rising of Arcturus, just now rising long enough before the Son to be visible in the morning. Within a week of Starlight mornings I shall see him. My fingers and feet were pinched to see the rising of the Sun from the corner of Charles’s house; but it was a glorious sight— The surface of the ground wherever the eye could range was covered with hoar frost; but the temperature of the atmosphere softened much in the course of the day.— The Revd. Augustus R. Pope, of Kingston, near Plymouth officiated at the Temple by exchange with Mr Lunt. His morning text was from Luke 22.32. “But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not: and when thou art converted strengthen thy brethren.” It is the saying of the Saviour to Peter, forewarning him of his approaching desertion at the last Supper.— Mr Pope remarked upon the strangeness of the fact, that Jesus, the Messiah, at the moment when he was about to suffer an ignominious death, should have prayed that the faith of his disciple Peter might not fail, when he knew and foretold to Peter himself that it would— But he foretold also that Peter would recover from the fall of his frailty, and exhorts him when he is converted to strengthen his brethren— The Sermon was chiefly a discourse upon Faith— Simon (Peter’s) faith was to fail notwithstanding the prayer of Jesus—he was yet to be converted, and then was to strengthen the faith of his brethren. Since my own Dissertation upon Faith, which palls a little upon my Memory I have heard several Sermons from Clergymen on the same Subject, all of which have given me further ideas regarding it, but none has presented an exact analysis of it as an intellectual and sensitive property of men. Mr Pope enumerated the various senses in which the word Faith is used in the Scriptures without remarking upon the analogy between them— He dined with us, and I made several enquiries of him concerning the family of old judge Sever, at whose house I once slept in April 1787. and of his son, John Sever my Classmates— They are both long since dead but many descendants of John and his brother James remain. Mr Pope’s afternoon Sermon was from James 1.22. [“]But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.” After the service I called to see Mrs Charles who still keeps her bed— He was here this evening.

Lewis Bass, Collector of the parish tax, called on me this morning for payment of mine for which I referred him to my Son— He said he wanted a supply to pay to Mr Lunt— He is chairman of the whig Committee of this town and asked me if my Address to the young Men’s Boston whig club, was printed in a pamphlet. I said it was not yet, but I expected it would be— He said the whig Committee had voted last Saturday Evening to purchase 200 copies of it for circulation— This explains the application of J. J. Carr to me for a contribution. Bass said he took the half weekly Daily Advertiser and had seen only the first half of my address; but he referred to so many passages in it, that he shewed he had read it attentively— My Son went to Boston this morning and took his boy John Quincy into the Latin School. He returned and dined with us, and was here again in the Evening. He brought out a note of invitation to him and to me, from William Sawyer, to dine with him to-morrow— I received from President Quincy last week an invitation to attend the exhibition at Cambridge to-morrow— Before we had finished our dinner William Jackson of Newtown and his brother Francis Jackson came in; returning from a tour to Plymouth to examine the course of the Old Colony Rail-road.— William Jackson is the Candidate of the Liberty party for the Office of Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth. Francis Jackson is of the party who take no part in the Government because it requires an Oath to support the Constitution of the United States— William Jackson told me that he went to the Liberty party Convention last week at Dedham to prevent if possible the nomination of a Candidate for Congress against me— But he found it impossible— They were exceedingly zealous. He said he hoped I should be re-elected, but considered it doubtful— Mr William H. Story came from Brooklyn, New-York, with an invitation to me to preside over a whig mass-meeting there, on the 24th. of this month, which I declined, and I wrote also to Mr Halsey declining the invitation to read my address to the young men of Boston, on the Evening of the 23d at the Tabernacle in New-York. I regret much that I could not accept that invitation— Ruth Turner was again here this day— In the evening came on rain and the prospect of foul weather to morrow— My task is the daily page of the journal and three pages of preparation for the address to my Constituents. This is the ne plus ultra.

div.dateline: Quincy, Tuesday 15. October 1844. Cambridge. Boston. Quincy.
div.p: How often Self-examination, is followed by self-reproach! and how often self reproach by self absolution and the neglect or forgetfulness of reform! I had determined to attend the exhibition at Cambridge this morning and to be there in Season at the Meeting of the Committee of Overseers at 10 O’Clock, to leave home at the latest by half past 8. The morning Newspapers came by the Mail, and among them, the National Intelligencer of last Saturday the 12th. instt. containing the whole of my Address of the 7th. to the young Men’s Whig club at Boston, and an idle curiosity to ascertain if it was correctly printed enticed me to read till I found the watch within five minutes of ten and that the Carriage had been an hour and a half in waiting— I hurried through Boston to Cambridge, and found the performances of the exhibitions just commenced, by a Latin Oration— There was a Prospectus of 14 performances, three of which were omitted— Three in Latin, two in Greek, & the rest in English— There was an English version of Chateaubriand’s Description of Jerusalem by Charles Eliot Norton of Cambridge A Latin Dialogue—translated from Sheridan’s Rivals. A Greek Dialogue from Moliere’s Fourberies de Scapin— A disquisition on the Offence and doom of André—by Frank Boott Goodrich of Roxbury A Dissertation upon American Eloquence—by Paul Willard of Charlestown— His antient American Orators were Patrick Henry and James Otis— The man of the Middle age Fisher Ames. The moderns Henry Clay and Daniel Webster— An English version of a Speech of Mirabeau to the National Assembly of 19. April 1790— A disquisition upon Philosophical and Religious Didactic Poetry—bottomless— A Greek version from Livy. A Dissertation upon the Satire in Gulliver’s Travels, by Charles Henry Glover of Nantucket—the most amusing part of the day.— He spoke of the Pilgrim’s Progress and Robinson Crusoe in parallel with Gulliver, as pre eminently pictures of English Life and manners.— The English Oration—the Reformer by Thomas Russell of Plymouth was not sparkling— After the performances I called at the President’s house, saw Mrs Quincy and her daughter Abby took her son Josiah junr to his house in Boston, passed an hour of heavy rain at Charles’s Office—took up again Josiah Quincy at his house, and went with him to N. 87. Mount Vernon Street where we dined, with my very old friend William Sawyer whom I had not seen for many years— The company were almost all old friends— I returned after dinner home.

Excessively hurried and delayed— My Son removed this day with his family to Boston— The further I proceed in my task, the more the field widens before me. I had received a Letter of the 24th of last Month from Francis Hilliard of Roxbury, Chairman of the whig Committee of the 8th Congressional District, inviting me to address my Constituents and the public, at such time and place as might be convenient and agreeable to myself— I had then just agreed to address the young men’s whig club at Boston, and had not even commenced that address.— I sent word by Mr Loring to Mr Hilliard, that I would comply with that invitation and fix the time and place for it after getting through with the young men of Boston— Ever since the 7th. I have been intending to write to Mr Hilliard, but he called on me this morning for my answer— I proposed to him this day fortnight the 30th. of this month at 10. O’Clock in the morning.— The place I left entirely at the discretion of the Committee to select; wishing only to suit the persons who will be likely to attend, that they may be put to as little inconvenience as possible— I had suggested to Mr Loring the expediency of notifying the towns of the District and proposing to them to send delegations to attend the meeting, which Mr Hilliard said he thought they would do.— With regard to the place Mr Hilliard went and consulted with Mr Brigham, and returned and said they proposed to apply for the use of the church at the Weymouth landing to which I readily agreed. He asked if I thought of adding any religious solemnity to the meeting. I said I should be glad that the meeting should be opened with prayer, by the Minister of the Church, or if he should be reluctant by Dr Richard Storrs the Minister of the next Orthodox Church at Braintree— And so the arrangement was concluded— Mr George S. Foster is a young man, a member of the Young Men’s Henry Clay Association of New York.— He came for the purpose of persuading me to attend at their mass meeting next Wednesday, and to deliver over again that evening in the Tabernacle, my address to the young Men of Boston— I told him how much I regretted that I could not perform and that I had answered the invitation from Mr Halsey to that effect. He then said that they would have a printing press in the procession, and want an address to be struck off and circulated while the procession is moving. He urged me very warmly to write such an address but I declined. I wasted too much time and a little anger upon a Letter of Langdon Cheves about the Tariff, Texas, Nullification and disunion— Evening not idle.

I received my manuscript of the Address, from the Atlas Office, but its publication in pamphlet form is yet problematical.— I have revised the errors of the publication in the Atlas, and have made up 20 copies and distributed them among several individuals my friends in several quarters of the Union— I shall soon be called to reply—to furious assaults from the worthies, whose characters and exploits I have brought in relief before the civilized world.— My main object now is the address to my Constituents to be delivered on the 30th. of this month—but in the review of the proceedings at the last Session of Congress I must make a selection of the topics which I am to discuss.— They are, 1. The choice of a Speaker whose election was contested. 2. The prostration of the Law prescribing elections by single districts. 3. The exclusion from the Journals of the protest against the subversion of the Law. 4. The abortive effort to discard the gag rule which I am yet discussing. Then come the Massachusetts Resolutions and the proceedings of the House upon them— The bill to refund Jackson’s fine— The threatened repeal of the Tariff of 1842.— The Oregon fever.— The Texas fever and Treaty— The Treaty with the German Customs Union, and the complicated intrigues and cabaling for the annexation of Texas; with the three Baltimore Conventions— The whig nomination of Henry Clay, and Theodore Frelinghuysen— The mock democratic nomination of John Tyler without a Vice President— The smuggled nomination of James K. Polk, and George M. Dallas— The political contortions of John C. Calhoun, and the disunion schemes of R. Barnwell Rhett and Langdon Cheves, all form a compound subject for discoursing to my Constituents. Of all these I must make a selection of which the Slave representation may be the common bond— A large portion of my time this day was consumed in a revolutionary Letter of Langdon Cheves. There is an almost insuperable difficulty in my way, that I cannot discuss these matters without bearing upon the Presidential canvas— Mr Beale and his two daughters spent the Evening here— It was my only interruption, yet I was up till 11. at Night.— I received the first and second number of a new weekly Newspaper, published at Boston called the Plain Dealer—professing Democracy, but striking at the prominent Men of all parties—except Thomas H. Benton.

The pressure upon my brain increases and my time becomes so totally absorbed in writing that I have now Memory for scarcely any thing that passes from day to day. This day, besides the journal of yesterday I wrote four pages of my task, an atchievement which I shall probably never again perform. Mr G. W. Bryant came from North Bridgewater, and invited me to go and address a meeting of the people there— He said the Liberty party were making very great exertions there, and were speciall working for a concert with the Democracy; and they were detaching so many from the whigs, that they were apprehensive of losing the election of their candidate to represent the town in the State Legislature— I told him that I had promised to address the people of the 8th. Congressional District on the 30th. of this Month— I had left it to the whig Committee of the District to fix upon the place where the Address should be delivered, and I understood they had agreed upon Weymouth landing.— But I could divide my address in two, and deliver part of it at one place and part at another, and if he would see Mr Francis Hilliard of Roxbury, Mr Brigham of this town, Minott Thayer of Braintree or Thomas Loring of Hingham, and could make an arrangement with them, I would go to North-Bridgwater at any one or two days before or after the meeting at Weymouth landing. Doctor Nathaniel Miller of Franklin, came also to enquire if I could not visit that town or that part of the County, where he said the Liberty party were extremely busy and courting favour with the Democracy— He made some enquiries about the deputation from that party which visited me, and particularly about M. M. Fisher of Medway. At their convention at Dedham there were 55 votes taken of which there were 36. for Appleton Howe 14 for me, and 5 for this Mr Fisher. Their Presidential Candidate James G. Birney has come to Boston to electioneer for himself— He has been nominated by a Convention of Democrats at Saginaw in the State of Michigan, as a member of the State Legislature, and is throwing off his mask, and still trying to hide his face behind it— This coalition secretly concerted and just now coming out in its true colours will certainly break down the election in this 8th. District for the next Congress. I hope I may not take it too much at heart, but that it will prepare me for retirement for the rest of my days.

Warm rain with a furious storm of wind all last night and continued all the morning of this day.— I still drudge without seeing when I can come to a close— I received this morning a Letter from John P. Kennedy of Baltimore, thanking me for my exposure of that infamous fraud concocted by Andrew Jackson, George W. Erving, Aaron Vail Brown, and Charles J. Ingersoll, with the two Lewises and other understrappers, for the destruction of my character; and to accomplish the annexation of Texas and a fourth part of Mexico to the United States. But he gives me warning that I shall have the whole swarm of hornets upon me; and I must make up my mind to meet them— In the progress of my address to my Constituents I am now coming to the encounter with the deepest, the cunningest and the foulest rascal of them all— With the bold dashing utterly base and baseless lies of Andrew Jackson, I shall have not much trouble, and no danger but of assassination not by him, but by one or another of his blood-hounds. With George W. Erving, I shall have easy work if I can get hold of him; for his revelations have not yet been made public, and I only know that the Statements drawn from them by Jackson, Brown and Ingersoll are all equally false— Brown’s Note, upon Jackson’s Letter is of itself enough to demolish him—he can never get over it.— Ingersoll’s falsehoods, are more cautiously covered and more dexterously combined— There is cunning as well as impudence in his publishing his report as the report of the Committee of foreign Affairs, although they rejected it— The mountebank mock solemnity with which he announces the revelations of George W. Erving to Jackson, may not perhaps be so easy to turn into ridicule, nor will it be so light a task to unravel his web of sophistry and chicanery, woven from Ervings sleezy threads, as to unty the coarse and clumsy knots of Jackson and Brown— To an impartial jury I should have but a plain tale to tell and the whole fabrick of knavery would fall to pieces—but with prejudice, faction, false popularity and unbridled profligacy, what will be the event?— The odds are fearful— May God defend the right— This afternoon Walter Hellen went into Boston with My Granddaughter Mary Louisa— She remained there at my Son’s house. He returned early in the Evening— Mrs De Windt came in this Evening from her residence at Fishkill landing. She comes alone to visit her unfortunate Son, John who is at Dr Bell’s at Charlestown— Her daughter Anna Maria is at Brattleborough—Vermont.— Sore afflictions.

Mr Lunt preached this morning from Matthew 21.28. [“]But what think ye? A certain man had two sons; and he came to the first and said, Son, go work to-day in my vineyard. 29. He answered and said, I will not: but afterward he repented, and went. 30. And he came to the second and said likewise. And he answered and said, I go, sir, and went not. 31. Whether of them twain did the will of his father— They say unto him the first”— The discourse was a comme̅n̅y upon the whole parable, and one of the most pleasing Sermons I ever heard from Mr Lunt— He dissected the whole story—filled up the outline of the contrasted character of the two Sons—delineated the characters of two others, who might be of the same family— The one who upon being commanded by his father to go, work upon his vineyard, should answer at once I go, and should actually go—the best of the family—and the worst who should on receiving the command, should refuse obedience and act accordingly— He remarked upon almost every separate word of the narrative. Go Work—expatiated on the Nature of the command to work—active and useful industry—to day not waiting till to-morrow—and he closed with an Arabian Apologue about Bén Hassan to whom a Genius came and called him up to do some act of diligence, but who pleaded for indulgence from day to day, till Death came in the place of the Genius and would listen to no delay.— Mr Lunt occasionally digressed from the parable to the context and remarked upon the manner in which he avoided answering the question by what authority he performed his miracles—retorting upon them by a question whether they think the baptism of John from Heaven or of men? and when they answer they cannot tell he rejoins neither tell I you by what authority I act, not saying as they did that he cannot tell, but predicating his refusal upon their pretence of inability— Mrs De Windt left us this afternoon, and went to Mr John Angiers at Medford. She had come from Albany last Thursday, to Mr George T. Bigelow’s at Boston, and came out last evening with Mr and Mrs Bigelow from Boston.— Mr Lunts afternoon Sermon was from 1. John 3.7. [“]Little children, let no man deceive you. He that doeth righteousness is righteous, even as he is righteous”—that is as Christ the Son of God is righteous— The doctrine is that all righteousness consists of deeds and not of words— The Acadia Steamer arrived from Liverpool this afternoon at 4. O’Clock at Boston— At 2 and at half past 3 I had looked for her from the hill, but did not see her.
Bright Northern light when I rose.

Mr Bryant, the chairman of the whig club at North Bridgewater came again, and I agreed with him to go there and address the People at ten O’Clock in the morning, rain, snow or shine on Wednesday the 6th. of next Month— I am to go to Bennet’s Hotel, and must be there by 9 in the morning— While he was here, Mr C. C. P. Waterman of Sandwich on Cape Cod came with an invitation from Zenas R. Hinckley and five others a Committee of the whigs of that Town, to meet and address them, when it will best suit my convenience— I was obliged to decline this, having undertaken already more than I fear I shall be able to perform—that is to address my Constituents twice at two different places before I go to Washington, and before the approaching election— I have also received written invitations from W. D. Ely Corresponding Secretary of the Young Men’s Institute at Hartford Connt. to open a course of Lectures for the Winter for them there; in a Letter of 8 October transmitted to me with one of 17. October, from Boston, from John P. Putnam— From H. S. M’Call, Chairman of the Lecture Committee of the Young Mens Association at Albany to address them on my way to Washington, about the middle of November.— From Charles A. Stetson, and four others, who have resolved upon a public celebration in aid of the funds of the Washington Monument Association in New-York on the 25th. of November next— They say the occasion will be one of peculiar interest and my presence and participation in the ceremonies are earnestly and respectfully solicited— These with multitudes of others, of little comparative interest remain unanswered. An old Clergyman from Providence, by the name of Thomas Williams, who has been here before came with a young man, named Jonas Reynolds Perkins a son of the Minister at the Weymouth Landing, a graduate three years since of Brown University, and now a student at Law, with Mr Coffin of New Bedford, and had a long conversation with me upon speculative politics and religion. I deposited at the stone Bank an order of my Son upon the Merchant’s Bank—Boston, for 500 dollars, and drew 200 which I gave to my wife for her journey to Washington, and 100 for my current expenses here. I called at the Aurora Office and asked Mr Clapp if he proposed to publish my Address to the young Men’s whig club at Boston— He said he would, and I promised him a revised copy, from the Boston Atlas— My Son came out from Boston with Mary-Louisa but returned almost immediately to Boston, himself— My wife had intended to take her departure for Washington this day, but was deterred by the prospect of foul weather and postponed her journey till to-morrow—

In my Address to the young Men’s whig club at Boston, I alluded to an incident in the Roman History merely from Memory, and in my extreme hurry I hazarded it, without verifying it by recurrence to Rollin or Livy— After the delivery of the discourse, I have felt a desire to verify my recollection of the facts and asked Walter Hellen and Mary-Louisa, to look it up in Rollin— I found it myself this morning, first in Rollin, and afterwards in Livy, 3.71— The event occurred in the 309th. year ab urbe condita—at the close of a war with the AEqui and Volsci— The dispute was between the Ardeates and Aricini and the people were wheedled into the judgment by an old soldier 83 years of age named Scaptius who started up in the Assembly of the people and declared that he would not suffer his country to be cheated out of her property— That he himself had fought in the battle when that same territory was taken, and would not without remonstrance see it taken away. The People and their Tribunes took fire— The Consuls and Senators struggled in vain to shame them out of their self-degradation in adjudicating the territory to themselves— Scaptius and the tribunes prevailed and the territory was re-annexed— This consultation of Livy was a temptation to dally with Time, to commune with him further but I broke away from him and wrote four pages of my proposed address, besides the journal of yesterday— I took nevertheless to Mr Clapp the publisher of the Quincy Aurora, the Boston Atlas of the 9th. with the errors of the press in my address to the young men’s whig club at Boston— He said he would publish it in two papers commencing next week, and would send me proof sheets to revise before the publication— My wife postponed again her departure for Washington till to-morrow— But she went this afternoon with Mrs John Adams, Mary-Louisa, and Walter Hellen into Boston, and took tea at my Son’s, with his wife.— He himself was dining at Mr Abbott Lawrence’s, with Mr. Daniel D. Barnard of Albany, who came to Boston to deliver a Lecture before the Boston Lyceum and an Address to the young men’s whig club; which last took place last evening. The party got back this evening about 9. O’Clock. While they were gone Mr and Mrs. Goodrich (he the author of Peter Parley[)] came and took tea with us. He afterwards delivered a political address to the whigs of Quincy at the town Hall, which for want of time I did not attend.

Immediately after rising this morning I saw for the first time this Season my old acquaintance Arcturus about 5 minutes risen— I had been looking for him about a fortnight from the direction of the two Stars in the tail of Calisto, and should no doubt have seen him some days earlier had there been a clear sky. His rise now is from 5 to ten minutes before five— Walter Hellen went into Boston in the Stage at nine O’Clock and precisely at 2 p.m. my wife, with Mrs John Adams, Mary Louisa, and the black boy William Queen went into Boston in our own Carriage. I went with them, and reaching the depot of the Western Rail-road opposite the United States Hotel at 3. found Walter Hellen waiting there, and my Son, to see them off. They took their seats in the car for Springfield, and found Mr Barnard going the same way, on his return to Albany— At a quarter past 3 they started, and I went with Charles to his house— I saw there his wife and daughter—but none of the sons. Mrs Charles was in her chamber, feeble, but not so much indisposed as she was the last ten days at Quincy— At 4. I went with Charles to Mr Josiah Quincy’s where we dined, with a company with whom I should meet no where else—President Quincy; Mrs Greene his daughter with her husband—Mr Brimmer the Mayor of the city—Mr Cary the son in Law of Thomas H. Perkins—Isaac P. Davis—Doctor Howe, Director and Secretary of the Perkins Institution and Massachusetts Asylum for the blind, and Henry W. Longfellow Smith Professor of the French and Spanish Languages and Literature, and Professor of Belles Lettres, at Harvard University— A literary and somewhat Scientific Society— I had ordered Benjamin to be with the Carriage at Mr Quincy’s door at 6. but it was half past 7. before I left the table— I came home by Moonlight and reached my house shortly before the sound of the curfew bell at 9. O’Clock— Our parlor family is now reduced to my Cousin Louisa Catherine Smith and me.

Isaac P. Davis told me that there were in the Globe Newspaper of last Saturday and Monday two long Articles on my address to the young men’s whig club in Boston.— My Son is to go to deliver a political address to-morrow, at Fitchburg in the County of Worcester, and the evening after he is to discourse at Lynn.— While I was at Boston this afternoon Mr Minott Thayer called at my house with an invitation for me, and all my friends to dine with him next Wednesday, after the delivery of my Address, an invitation which annoys me greatly. I endeavoured this evening after retiring to my chamber to redeem the loss of the morning but found it impracticable.— Took to my bed before ten.

I saw Sirius again, about 5 minutes risen. He rose, as near as I can estimate 10 minutes before 5.— The morning was very chilly. The Sun rose perfectly clear and his Southern strides are now visible from one day to another— The pressure upon my time and nerves is indescribable. Mr S. T. Armstrong has been one of the truest friends that I have met with in this world.— He came out from Boston this morning to invite me to dine with him which I engaged to do, this day fortnight the 7th. of November— He was present and heard my address to the young men’s whig club at Boston. He retains more of any discourse of mine that he hears than any other person. He told me this day that he had never before heard that the value of amber was increased by the preservation of insects in it— I found the fact stated in Rees’s Encyclopaedia— This afternoon Miss Catherine Thaxter called here with a cousin of hers, apparently of a later generation whom she introduced as Miss Susan Thaxter.— Catherine spoke of my father and mother, and said she was here at the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage—which was of course the 25th. of October 1814. and she well remembered hearing my father say then to my mother that he loved her as dearly as he did on the wedding day.— The Revd. Jonas Perkins minister of the Church in Braintree at the Weymouth landing called towards evening— There is the place where on the 17th. of September 1842 I addressed my Constituents of the then 10th. District and there is the place where I am to address next Wednesday my Constituents of the present 8th. District— As the performance is to be introduced by a religious invocation, Mr Perkins asked me, if I should have any objection to that solemnity’s being performed by Mr Thomas Williams of Providence, who was here a few days since. I said none, if it would be agreeable to Mr Perkins himself.— He said Mr Williams had expressed to him his wish to officiate and he was willing to gratify him— I requested Mr Perkins if he should on his way home pass by Mr Minott Thayer’s house, to call on him, and say to him that I was grateful to him for his kind invitation to dinner on that day, but that I shall be obliged to return home to dine—and that I begged him not to be at any expence for entertaining any company on that day— My feelings are very different at the prospect of this meeting, from what they were on that occasion— All is now gloomy and discouraging, with a double opposition before me, and all but a certainty of failing to carry the election.
Sun rose 6.24. Set 5.5.— Hoar frost. F. 30.

My only interruption of a visitor this day was Mr Lunt who brought me a Letter from the Revd. C. Briggs, inviting me to deliver a Lecture at the opening of the Lyceum in Roxbury two or three weeks hence— I have not time even to answer the invitation, and have numbers of unanswered invitations before me— But I wrote this day the journal of yesterday, and four pages of the address for next Wednesday at Braintree. This hurried composition however has so pernicious effect upon the style, that my heart sinks within me at the thought of what I am going to deliver, and my only hope is in striking about half of what I have written. About half an hour before dinner I took a walk round the garden, nursery and Orchard, looking into the seminary— The desolation of the Season cast a gloom on my spirits— The fruit has been gathered from all the trees except one bearing Quince tree on the borders of the pond— The ground is strewed with sere red and yellow leaves—the ground is wet and gathered in clods— Kirke has taken up a number of my seedlings and cut down others— Most of the large trees are mere stems, stripd of all their leaves— I hastened in from this prospect to dinner— I afterwards met in the garden Mrs Green the daughter of Mr and Mrs Kirk, wife of John A. Green editor of the Quincy Patriot— I had not seen her since her marriage, and did not at first know her— Again as the Sun went down, I walked up the Hill to Charles’s house to see the Sun set. But although it was not quite 5. O’Clock the Sun was already behind Mount Ararat.— I went further over the hill and surveyed the village, the surrounding country; the harbour and bay of Boston. The State house of Boston itself and the shaft of the Bunker-hill Monument; and Memory returned to the fact that this day 80 years ago, my father and mother were united in marriage— What an ordo seculorum commenced for me from that day. What was then the condition of the People who then constituted the town of Braintree— What is the condition of the People of the three towns of Quincy, Braintree and Randolph now? And what will be the condition of the occupiers of the soil of these three towns in 80 years from this day? The recollection of the past is pleasing and melancholy— The prospect of the future— Oh! how gloomy it is! Not a soul now lives, who was then in the bloom of life— Not a soul now living will be here in 1924.— My own term—how soon it will close! And to whom will all this belong in 80 years from this day? Will prayer to God preserve the branches and shoots from my father’s Stock What a phantasmagoria is human life!
Sun rose 6.24. Set 5.4. behind Mount Ararat.

Mr Loring was here this morning alarmed at the double opposition of the democracy and the Liberty party, each playing into the other’s hands to defeat my election—each holding up an ex-Senator from the County of Norfolk in the State Legislature against me; neither expecting to elect their own candidate, but purposely combining to exclude me— I have no doubt of their success, and only ask to meet the exigency with a proper spirit. Leavitt in the morning Chronicle, hints that the object of the Liberty party in defeating my election is to force me upon the Legislature as a candidate for the Senate and then to give a chance for Appleton Howe’s election as the member for the District.— The electioneering of the Liberty party from Birney their head down—is more knavish than that of either of the others— Mr John Belcher of Randolph came and said he was deputed by the whigs of that place to invite me to visit and address them; which I told him, would much to my regret be impossible— He said they had no hopes of carrying a majority for me in that town but would do, what they could— Mrs John Angier of Medford, and Mrs Susan Boyd with her infant daughter Anna were here— Mrs Angier spoke to me of her deposit in the Life Insurance Company the annual income from which she had requested three or four years ago might be left to accumulate, she now desires to receive all the interest that has accumulated and whatever may hereafter accrue from year to year— Mrs Angier has an extraordinary taste for painting and I saw on Wednesday last at my Sons house a beautiful head of a child in water colours painted by her— I had received a pretty Letter this morning from Charles’s daughter Louisa Catherine, urging me to go into Boston and spend as much of next week there as I can, as she is going next Saturday to Mrs Sedgwick’s school at Lenox and will probably not see me again for a year or more— She was to come out with her father this morning but was unwell and did not come— He came out with his two sons Charles and Henry; dined with us and returned to Boston— I had visits this afternoon from Edward Brooks and Thomas W. Phillips a son of my old friend John Phillips and a brother of Wendell Phillips. I finished this morning my proposed address to my Constituents and am so exceedingly disgusted with it that I made an attempt to begin anew with an introduction which may touch the interests of my hearers themselves.

I was somewhat disturbed in the Night, and not a little disordered through the course of this day. Mr Lunt had told me that he should preach at home this day but he exchanged with Mr Stearns of Hingham. The morning text was from Matthew 18.14. [“]Even so it is not the will of your Father which is in heaven that one of these little ones should perish”— The Sermon had obviously been composed by way of consolation to some person who has lost a child. Jonathan Bass had a note up for the loss of a grand child; and the father and mother one for the loss of their child. I suppose the discourse was adapted to this occasion and perhaps may administer comfort to some persons.— But Rachel refused to be comforted for her children because they were not.— This eighteenth chapter of Matthew is a fruitful field of meditation. It begins by stating that after the transfiguration, Jesus being at Capernaum, and having performed a miracle to procure money to pay tribute for himself and for Peter, the disciples came and asked him who should be greatest in the kingdom of heaven— Was there not some connection between his paying the tribute and that question—and surely there was a rebuke in his answer.— He told them that they who made themselves like little children would be the greatest in the kingdom of heaven and that no others would be admitted there.— Then he gave them that mysterious charge if any of their own members offended them to cast them off, and proceeds to say that it is not the will of their heavenly father that any one of the little ones should perish— Other injunctions of infinite importance follow, and the parable of the two debtors— Mr Stearns stopped at the promise to little children that none of them shall perish. He argued that they come into the world for a wise and benevolent purpose—that they afford comfort to their parents while they live, and that however prematurely taken away they leave to those whose affections they have engaged here the hope of meeting them in bliss hereafter.— The contemplation is sad and we can come after all to no other conclusion than resignation and submission to the will of heaven. Mr Stearns dined with Louisa C. Smith and me, and preached in the afternoon from John 13.34. “A new commandment I give unto you, That ye love one another; as I have loved you, that ye also love one another.” Love is the essence of Christianity—but the love enjoined by this precept is not precisely the same with that commanded for the neighbour.— Love is a song of degrees— Parental filial conjugal love, friendship, gratitude, veneration, compassion are all diversified forms of one benevolent impulse of the heart, which the Christian must cherish and regulate.

A stormy Night, and stormy day succeeding it. No rain yesterday—not much last Night or this day but an occasional drizzling mist, and a heavy North-eastern gale through both days. I am still disordered and was up twice last Night. Mr Charles Clapp, editor of the Quincy Aurora brought me this morning a proof page of his next Thursday’s paper, containing about half of my address to the Boston young men’s whig club reprinted from the Atlas Newspaper, with my revisal— I examined it without discovering any error in it— There are several errors in the Atlas copy—among which the substitution of the word vaccination for buccination which is ridiculous; and the more provoking as buccination was a word of my own coinage, which I ventured for its peculiar point in the application—for the sake of the walk a took back to Mr Clapp his proof page— Of the Letters that I received this day there was one from Abbott Lawrence, enclosing two to him from David S. Brown, and Charles W. Churchman, both of Philadelphia— Brown is a Quaker; both dated the 24th. stating that Daniel L. Miller junr. a respectable young Quaker and abolitionist would write me that same day a Letter of enquiries about Polk and Clay and Texas, and intreating Mr Lawrence to urge me to answer Miller’s enquiries, because many Quaker and abolition votes would depend upon my answer.— By the same mail there came to myself a Letter from Joseph R. Chandler, Charles Gibbons President of the National Clay Club, A. J. Lewis, Nathan Sargent, and Charles W. Churchman notifying me of this Letter of enquiries from Daniel L. Miller junr and urging me to answer it— Then two Letters from Miller both of the same date, one giving me notice of the other which contains three questions for my opinion— 1. Whether the Election of H. Clay would defeat the Texas-annexation.— 2. Whether the election of Polk would ensure it? 3. Whether the annexation of Texas would advance or retard the abolition of Slavery? I wrote a joking answer but know not how he will take it— I could not with propriety write any other— It is curious how the Polecat rascals work upon the Quakers, and to what base uses electioneering is turned— All the rest of this day, and until 11. at Night I was writing upon my address for next Wednesday— I want another week to finish it as a new draft— It will now be a thing of shreds and patches of which I am heart-sick.

The storm finally terminated by rain falling in torrents which began in the course of the last Night and all the former part of this day. Towards Sunset the storm subsided The Northeastern gale gradually sunk to a calm— A soft, damp, clammy state of the atmosphere succeeded still covered with murky clouds till as the Night darkened the stars of the western horizon first appeared, and before I retired to bed at 11. P.M. the sky was clear and waning moon was bright— What small incidents cheer or depress the Spirits! I was fretting all day with the terror of a similar day to morrow, and to the prospect of having to go tomorrow to Braintree through floods of rain, and then to deliver the address to empty walls— The brightening sky as I closed the writing of my address was delicious— A promise of a fair day to morrow; and I found upon a review, that the new introductory written since I finished the first draught last Saturday, with the last half of the first draught, would make a sufficiently well compacted discourse for a delivery of two full hours and I was at my ease.— But nothing less than the incessant toil of writing from the day after I addressed the young whigs of Boston could have produced this result. Though often called to extemporize I never do it with any satisfaction to myself— This morning as the floods of rain were falling a young man named Seymour, came on horseback from Boston, where he had arrived, by the night passage from New-York— He brought me a Letter from J. R. S. Van Vleet, Chairman of the Committee of arrangements of the whigs of New-York, who are to have another great procession of trades to-morrow among which will be the Printers; and they want me to write a short address to the People which they may print with my name, while they are moving— I told this young man it was impossible, being engaged day and Night in preparing an Address to be delivered to the People of my own district, to-morrow— He asked for a written answer, but I thought a verbal one sufficient.— The poor young man said he was very unwell and had not slept last Night— I pitied him— Mr Thomas Tileston came with his brother James, to ask the Manuscript of my address of tomorrow to print in the Courier with which he is connected— I told him it was engaged to the Atlas— He then spoke for the Address to be delivered at North Bridgwater next week, which I promised.

I rose with gratitude for the clear blue sky and saw the Sun rise from my Son’s house on the hill— The meeting was announced for half past ten— I went with Louisa C. Smith to Mr Minott Thayer’s house, where I was received by him with his accustomed kindness— There were about half a dozen persons there, chiefly those named in the margin— With Mr Putnam was Mr Simmons of Roxbury— Mrs Fogg an old Lady turned of 80, a sister of Mr Thayer, infirm and unable to leave her chamber sent a message requesting me to come up and see her, which I did— Her son and his wife were also there and live with Mr Thayer, who is a bachelor nearly of my age. Mrs Fogg knew my father, mother and all the family in the time of her and my childhood, but I was so early in my days absent from the country that she remembered not having ever seen me. Nor did I. There was a procession formed to meet me at Mr Thayer’s house and escort me to the Meeting house—with a small musical band; and Major Thomas Adams of Quincy was the Marshall. But the procession assembled slowly and it was past 11. before they came— I marched between Mr Thayer and Mr Francis Hilliard— There was a stand on a platform in front of the pulpit with a large folio bible upon it; and upon that bible I read my Address— The choir in the organ loft sung the hymn America— The Revd. Thomas Williams read the Chapter 1. Samuel 12.5 verses and made a short prayer. Mr Francis Hilliard, chairman of the District whig Committee, announced me as about to address the meeting, which I did for about two hours and a quarter; after which Mr Hilliard announced that there would be another meeting at the same place at half past 3. in the afternoon, but that I should not be present— I returned to Mr Minott Thayer’s, where there was a table laid for dinner and several friends there. Mr Thayer urged me to stay; but I had sent him word last week that I should be obliged to come home to dinner as I did with Miss Smith.— My address was well received.— The house was not filled. The democracy, had stretched a Polk and Dallas flag across the way under which the procession was to pass, but the wind blew it down— We got home at half-past two, well satisfied and grateful for the day.

Mr Thomas Tileston reporter for the Boston Courier was at the meeting at Braintree yesterday, and an abridged report of my address appears in the Courier of this morning. Mr Brewer of the Atlas Office was also there, who had written to me to ask my manuscript for it; and I gave it to him with a request that a proof sheet should be sent to me for revisal— While I was at dinner yesterday Mr Joseph Holmes of Kingston Plymouth County came in to enquire what was the condition of his petition to Congress about the Schooner Industry— I could not recollect, but left my dinner and looked over the Journal of the House of the last Session, and found nothing there concerning it.— Mr Holmes was in a stage, and had promised the driver not to detain him more than five minutes.— I promised him to look over the journals farther and ascertain and inform him— My last evening was not unoccupied, but I could only bring up my diary of the day before— This morning I was shortened for time, and came into Boston with Louisa C. Smith. Left her at Mr James H. Foster’s in Bedford Street, and came to my Son’s house 57. Mount Vernon Street— He went away yesterday to make speeches somewhere— Mrs Charles and her children are here.— At noon I attended a meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society at which 28 members were present— It was rather jocular than dignified and adjourned soon after one. An invitation was received from the New-York historical Society, to attend their anniversary Meeting on the 20th. of November— A Committee of five members was appointed to attend as a delegation from this Society and a Resolution was adopted that any other member of the Society who should be at New-York at that time should also attend as a delegate— Mr Saltonstall came in; just as the meeting was about to adjourn— Walking with me to the Atlas-Office he expressed his utter detestation of the Texas-annexation project. Mr Hayden of the Atlas Office had the manuscript of my yesterday’s address, and promised to send me to-morrow by 6. P.M a proof sheet to revise— I purchased at Libbey’s 159. Washington Street, a signet ring for my wife, and a breast pin for my granddaughter Louisa Catherine— I dined with a small party at my old friend ex-judge John Davis’s, his two widowed daughters being at table. At half past 3. we went to the Mason’s temple, and found Mr. John G Palfrey, commencing a Discourse on the 50th. anniversary of the Massachusetts Historical Society—very well written and handsomely delivered. I returned to my Son’s house, and spent the Evening with his wife and children, after calling at Mr. Abbott Lawrence’s— Not at home—
